definitions: of, relating to, or consisting of tiny organisms that drift in water
examples: Planktonic organisms form the base of many marine food chains
The planktonic stage of jellyfish drifts with ocean currents

definitions: arranged or scheduled beforehand according to a specific design or scheme
done or made intentionally rather than by accident or spontaneously
examples: The planned community features parks and walking trails
Their planned meeting was cancelled due to weather
The attack was clearly planned, not a random act
Every detail of the ceremony was carefully planned

definitions: of or relating to the sole of the foot in anatomy
examples: The plantar fascia supports the arch of your foot
Plantar warts appear on the bottom of feet

definitions: put into the ground to grow, as seeds or young plants
secretly placed in position for discovery by others, especially evidence
fixed firmly in place or established in a particular position
examples: The planted seeds sprouted after the spring rain
Newly planted trees need regular watering
The detective suspected the evidence had been planted
A planted story appeared in several newspapers
He stood with feet planted firmly apart
The idea was planted in her mind years ago

definitions: covered or coated with plaster material for walls or ceilings
very intoxicated from alcohol consumption in informal usage
examples: The plastered walls were painted white
Freshly plastered ceilings need time to dry
He got completely plastered at the party last night
She was too plastered to drive home safely

definitions: made from synthetic polymer materials that can be molded
capable of being shaped or formed, especially in artistic contexts
lacking genuineness or authenticity; appearing superficial or insincere
examples: The plastic containers are recyclable
Children played with plastic toys
Clay remains plastic when kept moist
The plastic arts include sculpture and ceramics
Her plastic smile didn't reach her eyes
The celebrity's plastic personality seemed manufactured

definitions: describing intimate affection between people without sexual or romantic involvement
of or relating to the philosophy of the ancient Greek philosopher Plato
examples: They maintained a platonic relationship despite their closeness
His feelings for her remained purely platonic
The platonic ideal represents perfect abstract forms
Students studied platonic dialogues in philosophy class

definitions: appearing worthy of belief or acceptance; seemingly valid, likely, or acceptable
examples: Her explanation seemed plausible enough to convince the jury
The theory offers a plausible account of the phenomenon

definitions: in suitable condition for playing, as a game or sports field
capable of being performed or played, as music or dramatic works
examples: The golf course is playable despite yesterday's rain
This video game is playable on multiple platforms
The difficult piano piece is barely playable
Shakespeare's works remain eminently playable today

definitions: having been performed, presented, or portrayed in past action
examples: The played match ended in a dramatic tie
A well played game deserves recognition

definitions: fond of games and amusement; frolicsome and full of high spirits
done in jest rather than seriously; teasing or humorous in manner
examples: The playful puppy chased its tail in circles
Children were in a playful mood after school
She gave him a playful punch on the arm
His playful teasing made everyone laugh

definitions: making an emotional appeal; earnestly requesting or begging for something
examples: Her pleading eyes made it hard to refuse
The defendant's pleading tone moved the jury

definitions: giving a sense of satisfaction or enjoyment; agreeable to experience
having an agreeable manner; amiable and good-natured in social interaction
examples: We had a pleasant walk through the park
The weather was pleasant for an outdoor wedding
She's always pleasant to work with
The waiter was pleasant and attentive

definitions: feeling or showing pleasure and satisfaction, especially at an event or situation
examples: She was pleased with her exam results
The coach looked pleased after the team's victory

definitions: giving satisfaction, pleasure, or contentment to the mind or senses
examples: The garden has a pleasing arrangement of colors
Her voice had a pleasing musical quality

definitions: providing or capable of providing pleasure, enjoyment, or gratification
examples: Reading is a pleasurable way to spend an evening
The spa treatment was a pleasurable experience

definitions: lacking in refinement; coarse or vulgar in manner or taste
of or relating to the common people in ancient Rome or generally
examples: His plebeian tastes ran to fast food and beer
The restaurant's plebeian atmosphere appealed to locals
The plebeian class demanded representation in government
Plebeian families lived outside the city walls

definitions: bound by or having made a solemn promise or undertaking
examples: The pledged delegates must vote as instructed
All pledged funds will support the charity

definitions: complete in every respect; absolute and unqualified in power or authority
examples: The ambassador has plenary powers to negotiate
A plenary session includes all conference participants

definitions: existing in large quantities; abundant and more than adequate in supply
examples: Fresh water is plentiful in this region
The harvest produced plentiful crops this year

definitions: of or relating to the membrane surrounding the lungs and lining the chest cavity
examples: Pleural fluid helps the lungs expand smoothly
The patient developed a pleural effusion

definitions: easily bent or shaped without breaking; flexible and supple
easily influenced or controlled; readily adapting to others' wishes
examples: The pliable leather molded perfectly to the foot
Pliable branches are ideal for weaving baskets
Young minds are more pliable than older ones
He proved too pliable for strong leadership

definitions: progressing slowly and steadily with persistent but uninspired effort
examples: His plodding style of writing lacked excitement
The plodding pace of the meeting frustrated everyone

definitions: marked or drawn on a map, graph, or chart with coordinates
planned secretly, especially something illegal or harmful against someone
examples: The plotted course showed the ship's intended route
Data points were carefully plotted on the graph
They plotted their escape for months
The conspirators plotted against the government

definitions: having soil turned over and broken up for planting, British spelling
examples: The ploughed fields were ready for spring planting
Freshly ploughed earth has a distinctive smell

definitions: having soil turned over and broken up for planting, American spelling
examples: The farmer surveyed his plowed fields
Recently plowed ground is ready for seeding

definitions: pulled off or out from where something is growing or attached
played by pulling and releasing strings with fingers rather than bowing
examples: The plucked chicken was ready for cooking
Freshly plucked flowers filled the vase
The plucked strings created a distinctive sound
Plucked instruments include guitars and harps

definitions: showing courage and determination in difficult circumstances despite being small or weak
examples: The plucky underdog team won against all odds
Her plucky attitude inspired everyone around her

definitions: having an opening blocked or filled with something to stop flow
connected to an electrical outlet or power source for operation
examples: The plugged drain caused water to back up
His plugged nose made breathing difficult
Make sure the device is properly plugged in
All plugged appliances should be turned off

definitions: covered with or characterized by feathers of a specified type or appearance
examples: The brightly plumaged parrot attracted many visitors
Beautifully plumaged birds performed mating dances

definitions: exactly vertical or perpendicular, as tested with a plumb line
complete and absolute; utter and thoroughgoing in informal usage
examples: The carpenter ensured the wall was plumb
The post needs to be plumb before cementing
He's plumb crazy about that new car
She was plumb exhausted after the marathon

definitions: adorned or decorated with feathers, especially as an ornamental display
examples: The plumed helmet belonged to a cavalry officer
Dancers wore plumed headdresses in the parade

definitions: having a full rounded shape; slightly fat in an attractive way
examples: The baby had plump rosy cheeks
She selected plump tomatoes from the garden

definitions: stolen goods by force, especially during war or civil disorder
examples: The plundered treasures were recovered years later
Plundered villages lay abandoned after the raid

definitions: engaged in stealing goods using force, especially in wartime
examples: The plundering army left destruction in its wake
Plundering pirates terrorized coastal towns

definitions: denoting more than one in grammar; relating to multiple entities or instances
examples: The plural form of 'child' is 'children'
Plural societies embrace diverse cultures

definitions: characterized by or advocating a diversity of views, cultures, or interests coexisting
examples: A pluralistic society values different perspectives
The university promotes pluralistic approaches to education

definitions: richly luxurious and expensive; characterized by comfort and extravagance
examples: They stayed in a plush hotel suite
The plush carpet felt soft underfoot

definitions: operated by or filled with compressed air or gas pressure
examples: The pneumatic drill broke through concrete easily
Pneumatic tires provide a smoother ride

definitions: cooked by simmering gently in liquid just below boiling point
illegally hunted or caught on someone else's land or in protected areas
examples: She ordered poached eggs on toast for breakfast
The poached salmon was perfectly tender
Poached ivory funds criminal organizations
Rangers found evidence of poached animals

definitions: having an imaginative or sensitively emotional style of expression
of, relating to, or characteristic of poetry or poets
examples: The sunset created a poetic scene over the lake
She has a poetic way of describing nature
His poetic works influenced modern literature
The class studied poetic devices and forms

definitions: of or relating to poetry; having qualities suitable for poetry
examples: His poetical works were published posthumously
The poetical society meets monthly to share verses

definitions: evoking a keen sense of sadness or regret; emotionally moving in a painful way
examples: The film's poignant ending left audiences in tears
Her poignant memoir described childhood poverty

definitions: having a sharpened or tapered tip or end for piercing
directed at a particular person or purpose with deliberate emphasis
examples: She used pointed scissors to cut fabric
The fence had pointed stakes on top
His pointed remarks about tardiness embarrassed her
She ignored his pointed stare across the room

definitions: having no purpose, use, or sense; lacking meaning or effectiveness
examples: Arguing with him seems completely pointless
They engaged in pointless bureaucratic procedures

definitions: balanced and prepared for movement or action; on the brink of
showing poise; having composure and self-assured dignity in manner
examples: The diver stood poised on the platform
The company is poised for expansion
She remained poised despite the pressure
The poised speaker commanded attention

definitions: containing or being a substance that causes injury, illness, or death
extremely unpleasant or malicious; having a harmful or corrupting influence
examples: Many poisonous mushrooms look like edible ones
The snake's poisonous bite required immediate treatment
Their poisonous relationship affected the whole family
Poisonous rumors spread throughout the office

definitions: annoyingly slow or dull; moving or proceeding at a sluggish pace
examples: The pokey old car held up traffic
This pokey computer takes forever to start

definitions: of or relating to the North or South Pole or polar regions
directly opposite in character, tendency, or point of view
examples: Polar bears live in Arctic regions
The polar ice caps are melting rapidly
They hold polar opposite political views
The twins have polar personalities

definitions: of or involving strongly critical, controversial, or disputatious writing or speech
examples: His polemic style alienated moderate readers
The polemic article sparked heated debate
